pico.title: Privacy-Preserving Agricultural Monitoring from Satellite Observations: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Field-level agricultural observations derived from satellite imagery including crop type classification, yield estimates, irrigation practices, fertilizer and pesticide application timing, tillage detection, and livestock density estimates from optical, SAR, and thermal sensors
pico.intervention: Privacy-preserving methods for producing regional and national agricultural statistics from farm-level satellite observations, including spatial aggregation schemes, differential privacy mechanisms, k-anonymity adaptations, secure multi-party computation for cross-organization analysis, and synthetic data generation
pico.comparison: Different aggregation units (field, farm, commune, district, region), various differential privacy epsilon values, different k-anonymity thresholds, unprotected field-level data sharing, and traditional survey-based agricultural statistics
pico.outcome: Statistical accuracy of agricultural indicators (crop area estimates, yield predictions, input use statistics), individual farm re-identification risk, compliance with agricultural data protection regulations (EU CAP, US Farm Bill privacy provisions), utility for agricultural policy decisions and market analysis, and computational/administrative feasibility
pico.research_question: For field-level agricultural observations derived from satellite imagery, how do different privacy-preserving aggregation and anonymization methods compare in producing accurate regional and national statistics while protecting individual farm-level information from re-identification?
pico.rationale: Precision agriculture and satellite-based crop monitoring generate unprecedented detail at the individual field level. While aggregate statistics are essential for food security policy, agricultural subsidies administration, commodity markets, and insurance pricing, individual farmers have legitimate privacy and commercial interests in their field-level management practices. The EU Common Agricultural Policy increasingly uses satellite monitoring for compliance verification, raising tensions between transparency and farmer privacy. This review synthesizes evidence on privacy-utility trade-offs to guide agricultural data governance frameworks.

sub_questions.title: Spatial Aggregation Unit Selection
sub_questions.population: Field-level crop type and yield data from satellite imagery
sub_questions.intervention: Aggregation at different spatial units (1ha, 10ha, 100ha, administrative boundaries)
sub_questions.comparison: Different aggregation unit sizes compared; fixed grid vs. adaptive aggregation
sub_questions.outcome: Crop area estimation accuracy, yield prediction reliability, re-identification risk for individual farms, minimum viable aggregation unit for privacy
sub_questions.research_question: What is the minimum spatial aggregation unit that provides meaningful privacy protection for farm-level satellite observations while maintaining useful agricultural statistics?

sub_questions.title: Differential Privacy for Crop Statistics
sub_questions.population: Aggregated crop statistics (area, yield, input use) derived from satellite monitoring
sub_questions.intervention: Differential privacy with various epsilon values (0.1 to 10) and composition strategies
sub_questions.comparison: True statistics without noise; different noise mechanisms (Laplace, Gaussian)
sub_questions.outcome: Absolute and relative error in crop area and yield estimates, privacy guarantee strength, utility for different downstream applications (policy, markets, research)
sub_questions.research_question: What epsilon values provide acceptable accuracy for agricultural statistics while offering meaningful privacy protection for contributing farms?

sub_questions.title: Re-identification Risk in Agricultural Satellite Data
sub_questions.population: Anonymized or aggregated agricultural datasets derived from satellite imagery
sub_questions.intervention: Re-identification attack methods using auxiliary information (cadastral data, subsidy records, public imagery)
sub_questions.comparison: Different anonymization techniques; different levels of auxiliary information availability
sub_questions.outcome: Re-identification success rate, fields at highest risk, effectiveness of different protection methods
sub_questions.research_question: How vulnerable are anonymized satellite-derived agricultural statistics to re-identification attacks using publicly available auxiliary data?
